Award.AwardTitle: TILE: Transform, Interact, Learn, and Engage for success in STEM education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is preparing for institution-wide transformation of teaching and learning practices at a large public research university. It is continuing to expand a process that has already begun, building infrastructure around a core initiative called TILE (Transform, Interact, Learn, and Engage for success in STEM education). TILE requires faculty implementers to invest in professional development and the University to invest in technology-rich classrooms. TILE classrooms are remodeled after the SCALE-UP classrooms used in physics and other disciplines in the physical sciences that have been proven to be effective learning environments when paired with appropriate pedagogy. SCALE-UP (Student-Centered Active Learning Environment for Undergraduate Programs) is a mature, proven evidence-based method of education that puts students in small groups around circular tables and engages them in active construction of knowledge. Using computers, they pull information from the Internet to use in active solving problems. In SCALE-UP the task of getting disciplinary content is shifted to the internet and the process of solving difficult problems occurs in small groups during class time, where students help one another and are guided by expert instructors. This model is currently in use in more than 100 institutions of higher education. Appropriate pedagogy is learned by faculty instructors through a professional development program at the university that has already been designed and implemented by the Center for Teaching and the Office of Information Technology Services.

TILE has the support of a number of faculty members and administrators, but the process of transformation is still in its early stages. There are a number of possible barriers and issues that are likely to be encountered in this institution as in all large research universities. The main goals of this project are to anticipate and prepare for those challenges and create a process for overcoming them. The goals of this project are:
* Assess the organizational climate for promoting and sustaining innovative teaching and learning practices in STEM departments
* Create a Leadership Institute to provide College and Department leadership with evidence-based practices for supporting teaching and learning at the department and program level.
* Create a process to iteratively increase the use of evidence-based scientific teaching and learning practices in STEM classes, particularly in general education and introductory STEM courses. Included in the plan to increase evidence-based teaching in an iterative process is a set of assessment tools that will measure the benefits for students derived from improved teaching and learning practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals of this project were to (1) assess the organizational climate for promoting and sustaining innovative teaching and learning practices in STEM department, (2) create a Leadership Institute to provide College and Department leadership with evidence-based practices for supporting teaching and learning at the department and program level, and (3) create a process to iteratively increase the use of evidence-based scientific teaching and learning practices in STEM classes, particularly in general education and introductory courses. We were able to document the range of instructional practices in science, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) courses across campus and collect survey and interview data to determine motivators and obstacles for changes to instructional practice. 

Analysis of classroom observations and survey data revealed that didactic lectures are still the most common instructional style, particularly in large introductory courses. However, there was also evidence that some departments were beginning to shift to more student-centered learning environments. This analysis also revealed that part of the challenge in promoting change is the inconsistent understanding of the terminology used to describe different practices. While instructors were more likely to accurately report the use of lecture, many instructors still did not use lecture as often (or as infrequently) as they reported. Comparing self-report data to classroom observations also indicated significant differences in what instructors considered to be “highly descriptive” of their practice – instructors who asked questions regularly throughout class and instructors who consistently asked one or two questions per class both considered “asking questions of students during class” to be highly descriptive of their teaching practices.

Classroom observation data was combined with observation data from researchers across the country to generate a more complete analysis of instructional practices in STEM across the nation. The resulting publication has provided additional impetus for the need to change institutional conversations around teaching and learning and provide more support for sustained adoption of evidence-based practices.

Analysis of survey and interview data indicates wide variability among faculty perceptions, conceptualizations of change, and understandings of evidence. These findings suggest reasons faculty do not respond uniformly to calls for change, and challenge educational developers and advocates of STEM education reform to be explicit about our own understandings of meaningful change and evidence-based pedagogical practices. For example, because we could not find a consistent definition for evidence-based teaching articulated in the STEM education literature (or in talking to stake-holders across campus), we have developed our own working definition to facilitate conversations across campus:

Evidence-Based Teaching refers to a broad set of classroom practices which have been established by research to support student learning, many of which are guided by the faculty member’s ongoing collection of evidence of student learning in their own classrooms as a basis for decisions about further teaching.

Because evidence-based teaching relies on real-time review of student learning in a course, it tends to be better supported by active classroom engagement, frequent low-stakes assignments and activities, and regular formative assessments of student progress.

We have used the results of our study to provide insights for campus leadership as to institutional barriers and misperceptions that impede the adoption of evidence-based instructional practices. We have engaged the provost’s office and other campus leaders into looking at ways to better support and reward instructors who engage in reflective practice to create a campus climate that values these efforts.
